repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Science and Technology University
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's outcome is assessed
            as unsatisfactory. Seven key lessons can be drawn from this
            project: 1) In view of the security and political
            developments of the nineties in Algeria, the Bank should
            have been able to consider different options, discuss them
            with the borrower, and eventually decide to restructure the
            project. 2) Implementation capacity should be rigorously
            assessed during preparation and regularly reviewed during
            implementation. 3) Competition for investment funds works
            better when basic needs of the universities are met prior to
            the start of the competition process. 4) Projects involving
            investment funds should not be considered for Board approval
            unless all the steps necessary for an effective and timely
            functioning of the competition process are taken. 5) With
            most centralized administrative systems, institutional
            reforms have to be based on a relevant set of legislative
            and regulatory measures. 6) The Bank should always make sure
            that there is sufficient commitment on the part of the
            borrower and that the commitment is formalized in an
            official government document. 7) In order for the Bank to
            effectively contribute to the implementation of a sectoral
            strategy, cooperation between the sector and the Bank should
            involve a continuos substantive dialogue.

5078990.trustfund: TF020250-FRENCH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF028065-CANADIAN CONSLT. COOP. PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Science and Technology University
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project assists the government in
            developing an institutional and operational framework
            designed to provide the university system with the freedom
            and support necessary to improve the quality, relevance and
            responsiveness of higher education.  It will test new
            institutional arrangements executed through the Ministry of
            Universities (MU).  These arrangements will be a precursor
            to an autonomous intermediary institution for the allocation
            of government funds to higher education that is expected to
            emerge from the refrom process.  It supports investment
            proposals selected from those proposed by the participating
            universities in the framework of their medium-term
            institutional development plans.  Both the plans and the
            investment proposals will be subject to rigorous peer review
            and benefit from international scientific advice.  The draft
            development plans reviewed by the Bank involve delegation of
            authority to the participating universities to enter into
            contractual arrangements with third parties while keeping
            full control over the resulting income and over all stages
            of procurement of goods and services.
